{"blocks":[{"key":"8m0pt","text":"Amount of DNA to be used and use of restriction enzyme","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":54}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"oeto","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjvk8","text":"If the target is rare in the DNA sample, do not carry out dilution of the DNA sample (unless PCR inhibitors are abundant) and increase the quantity of DNA (a maximum of 6µL per 20 µL reaction). If the target is abundant in the sample, it is possible to perform a dilution of the DNA sample, for example 1/100. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b153m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65gr1","text":"The use of restriction digestion is recommended above 66 ng DNA per reaction. Ensure that the restriction enzyme selected does not cleave the PCR target. The amount of total digested DNA should not exceed 1000 ng per 20 µL reaction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8l48v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dp6e","text":"Multiplexing","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":12},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2e6ps","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb3qe","text":"Multiple sets of primers and probes can be used simultaneously to target multiple targets. In this case, add them to the reaction mix at the same concentrations as indicated in the protocol, reducing the amount of water to be added proportionally. For multiplexing, use probes with different fluorescent dyes and ensure that the primers/probe sets are compatible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6033t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6tu4p","text":"The following precautions must be applied:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":42}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71uha","text":"
- Wear gloves throughout the extraction process
- Clean the bench with DNA-removing solution (e.g. DNA-off, DNA away).
- Use tips with filters to avoid contaminations
- All steps have to be performed into a specific DNA-work station (sterile area equipped with air filtration and UV systems)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2dtsv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cuq7h","text":"For any manipulation in a rare DNA room, provide complete equipment (disposable coat, cap, mask, shoe covers & gloves).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":119}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6mmkj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"1bfjk","text":"The aim of this protocol is the digital droplet PCR (ddPCR) quantification of DNA target(s) using primer and probe sets. This protocol is optimised for the analysis of environmental DNA (eDNA) samples (water, sediment, biofilm and soil matrices) and then rare DNA targets.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":28,"length":92},{"style":"bold","offset":156,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5csrr","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lrj6","text":"THe ddPCR can be performed using a QX600 or a QX200 droplet reader system, and this protocol begins after the DNA extraction step and ends with the droplet reading.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":100,"length":64}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8mftu","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1c9tt","text":"The ddPCR for probes  consists of the absolute quantification of samples using primers and fluorescent dye-labelled probes. The ddPCR technique used is based on the partitioning of samples into droplets by water-oil emulsion and the reading of the DNA signal in each droplet. Multiple eDNA targets can be specifically targeted using multiple primer and probe sets that are compatible.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":18},{"style":"bold","offset":37,"length":86},{"style":"bold","offset":274,"length":89}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lb63","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"au243","text":"The advantages of using the ddPCR are: the absolute quantification, the sensitivity and the repeatability of the method.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":43,"length":23},{"style":"bold","offset":72,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":92,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80l7n","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
